sap.ui.vk.tools.PointCloudSelectionTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a PointCloudSelectionTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getSelectionColor selectionColor} : float[] (default: [0, 1, 0, 1])
  • Events
    • {@link #event:groupAdded groupAdded} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:groupRemoved groupRemoved} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:currentGroupChanged currentGroupChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.svg.ContentManager.description:
Provides a content manager object that uses to load 2D content.

When registering a content manager resolver with {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver} you can pass a function that will load a model and merge it into the three.js scene.
sap.ui.vk.svg.ContentManager.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ContentManager. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Events
    • {@link #event:errorReported errorReported} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentManager#constructor sap.ui.vk.ContentManager} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.svg.ContentManager.helpDescription:
Provides a content manager object that uses to load 2D content.

When registering a content manager resolver with {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver} you can pass a function that will load a model and merge it into the three.js scene.

sap.ui.vk.Camera.description:
Provides the base interface for the camera.

The objects of this class should not be created directly. Use PerspectiveCamera or OrthographicCamera instead.
sap.ui.vk.Camera.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Camera. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getPosition position} : float[] (default: [0, 0, 0])
    • {@link #getTargetDirection targetDirection} : float[] (default: [1, 0, 0])
    • {@link #getUpDirection upDirection} : float[] (default: [0, 1, 0])
    • {@link #getNearClipPlane nearClipPlane} : float (default: 0.1)
    • {@link #getFarClipPlane farClipPlane} : float (default: 1.0)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.Camera.helpDescription:
Provides the base interface for the camera.

The objects of this class should not be created directly. Use PerspectiveCamera or OrthographicCamera instead.

sap.ui.vk.View.description: Provides the interface for the view.
sap.ui.vk.View.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new View. The objects of this class contain necessary information to reproduce current view including camera type, position and orientation as well as objects visibility property and their positions (if different from default) Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getViewId viewId} : string
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getDescription description} : string
    • {@link #getAspectRatio aspectRatio} : float
    • {@link #getAutoPlayAnimation autoPlayAnimation} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getTopColor topColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(238, 238, 238, 1)")
    • {@link #getBottomColor bottomColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(255, 255, 255, 1)")
    • {@link #getNavigationMode navigationMode} : sap.ui.vk.NavigationMode (default: NoChange)
    • {@link #getDimension dimension} : int
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.View.helpDescription: Provides the interface for the view.

aspectRatio.description: Aspect ratio for Safe Area (optional). This can be 0 to 25. Values above or below this range will be ignored.
aspectRatio.helpDescription: Aspect ratio for Safe Area (optional). This can be 0 to 25. Values above or below this range will be ignored.

sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.description:
Provides the ability to explore a Scene object's node structure.

The objects of this class should not be created directly, and should only be created via a call to {@link sap.ui.vk.Scene#getDefaultNodeHierarchy sap.ui.vk.Scene.getDefaultNodeHierarchy}.
sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new NodeHierarchy. The objects of this class should not be created directly, and should only be created via a call to {@link sap.ui.vk.Scene#getDefaultNodeHierarchy sap.ui.vk.Scene.getDefaultNodeHierarchy}. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Events
    • {@link #event:changed changed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeCreated nodeCreated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeRemoving nodeRemoving} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeReplaced nodeReplaced} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeUpdated nodeUpdated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.helpDescription:

The objects of this class should not be created directly, and should only be created via a call to {@link sap.ui.vk.Scene#getDefaultNodeHierarchy sap.ui.vk.Scene.getDefaultNodeHierarchy}.

sap.ui.vk.OverlayArea.description: Aggregation element for the Overlay Control
sap.ui.vk.OverlayArea.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new OverlayArea. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getKey key} : string
    • {@link #getPosition position} : string
    • {@link #getColor color} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(200, 50, 50, 0.3)")
    • {@link #getColorBorder colorBorder} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(200, 50, 50, 1.0)")
    • {@link #getColorSelect colorSelect} : string
    • {@link #getColorNonSelect colorNonSelect} : string
    • {@link #getDeltaColorHot deltaColorHot} : string (default: "RHLSA(0;1.3;1.0;1.0)")
    • {@link #getSelect select} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getChangeable changeable} : boolean (default: false)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:click click} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:contextMenu contextMenu} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:edgeClick edgeClick} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:edgeContextMenu edgeContextMenu} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:handleMoved handleMoved} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:handleContextMenu handleContextMenu} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:handleClick handleClick} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool.constructorDescription:
Base for all tool controls. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

  • Properties

    • {@link #getActive active} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getFootprint footprint} : string[]
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getGizmo gizmo} : sap.ui.vk.tools.Gizmo
  • Associations
    • {@link #getGizmoContainer gizmoContainer} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.core.Control)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:enabled enabled} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.

sap.ui.vk.threejs.ContentManager.description:
Provides a content manager object that uses the three.js library to load 3D files. When registering a content manager resolver with {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver} you can pass a function that will load a model and merge it into the three.js scene. The loader function takes two parameters:
  • parentNode - {@link https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/objects/Group THREE.Group} - a grouping node to merge the content into
  • contentResource - {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentResource sap.ui.vk.ContentResource} - a content resource to load
The loader function returns a {@link https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise Promise} object. If the loading the model succeeds the promise object resolves with a value with the following structure:
  • node - {@link https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/objects/Group THREE.Group} - the grouping node to which the content is merged into. It should be the parentNode parameter that was passed to the loader function.
  • contentResource - {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentResource sap.ui.vk.ContentResource} - the content resource that was loaded.
sap.ui.vk.threejs.ContentManager.constructorDescription: Constructor for a new ContentManager. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object. This class does not have its own settings, but all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentManager#constructor sap.ui.vk.ContentManager} can be used.
sap.ui.vk.threejs.ContentManager.helpDescription:
Provides a content manager object that uses the three.js library to load 3D files. When registering a content manager resolver with {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.addContentManagerResolver} you can pass a function that will load a model and merge it into the three.js scene. The loader function takes two parameters:
  • parentNode - {@link https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/objects/Group THREE.Group} - a grouping node to merge the content into
  • contentResource - {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentResource sap.ui.vk.ContentResource} - a content resource to load
The loader function returns a {@link https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise Promise} object. If the loading the model succeeds the promise object resolves with a value with the following structure:
  • node - {@link https://threejs.org/docs/index.html#api/objects/Group THREE.Group} - the grouping node to which the content is merged into. It should be the parentNode parameter that was passed to the loader function.
  • contentResource - {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentResource sap.ui.vk.ContentResource} - the content resource that was loaded.

sap.ui.vk.Scene.description:
Provides the interface for the 3D model.

The objects of this class should not be created directly. They should be created via {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector}.
sap.ui.vk.Scene.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Scene. The objects of this class should not be created directly. They should be created via {@link sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector}. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getDoubleSided doubleSided} : boolean (default: false)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor sap.ui.base.ManagedObject} can be used as well.

sap.ui.vk.Viewer.description:
Provides simple 3D visualization capability by connecting, configuring and presenting the essential Visualization Toolkit controls a single composite control. NOTE: To use this control the application developer should add dependencies to the following libraries on application level to ensure that the libraries are loaded before the module dependencies will be required:
  • sap.f
  • sap.ui.comp
sap.ui.vk.Viewer.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Viewer. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEnableSceneTree enableSceneTree} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowSceneTree showSceneTree} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableStepNavigation enableStepNavigation} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableNotifications enableNotifications} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowStepNavigation showStepNavigation} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowStepNavigationThumbnails showStepNavigationThumbnails} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getOverlayStepNavigation overlayStepNavigation} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEnableLayersPanel enableLayersPanel} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowLayersPanel showLayersPanel} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableElementsPanel enableElementsPanel} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowElementsPanel showElementsPanel} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnablePageGallery enablePageGallery} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowPageGallery showPageGallery} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableToolbar enableToolbar} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableProgressIndicator enableProgressIndicator} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowDrawerToolbar showDrawerToolbar} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getEnableMiniMap enableMiniMap} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowMiniMap showMiniMap} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getToolbarTitle toolbarTitle} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getShouldTrackVisibilityChanges shouldTrackVisibilityChanges} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getRecursiveSelection recursiveSelection} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getRuntimeSettings runtimeSettings} : object (default: {})
    • {@link #getWebGLContextAttributes webGLContextAttributes} : object (default: ...see text or source)
    • {@link #getHotspotsEnabled hotspotsEnabled} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowAllHotspots showAllHotspots} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getHotspotColorABGR hotspotColorABGR} : int (default: 0x590000BB)
    • {@link #getHotspotColor hotspotColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(89, 0, 0, 0.73)")
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContentResources contentResources} : sap.ui.vk.ContentResource[] (default)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:contentResourceChangesProcessed contentResourceChangesProcessed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:sceneLoadingSucceeded sceneLoadingSucceeded} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:sceneLoadingFailed sceneLoadingFailed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:sceneDestroying sceneDestroying} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionChanged selectionChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:fullScreen fullScreen} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:urlClicked urlClicked} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeClicked nodeClicked} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.Viewer.helpDescription:
Provides simple 3D visualization capability by connecting, configuring and presenting the essential Visualization Toolkit controls a single composite control. NOTE: To use this control the application developer should add dependencies to the following libraries on application level to ensure that the libraries are loaded before the module dependencies will be required:
  • sap.f
  • sap.ui.comp

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

contentResources.description: Content resources to load and display in the Viewer control.
contentResources.helpDescription: Content resources to load and display in the Viewer control.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

webGLContextAttributes.description:
Optional WebGL context attributes. A JSON object with the following boolean properties:
  • antialias {boolean} default value true. If set to true, the context will attempt to perform antialiased rendering if possible.
  • alpha {boolean} default value true. If set to true, the context will have an alpha (transparency) channel.
  • premultipliedAlpha {boolean} default value false. If set to true, the color channels in the framebuffer will be stored premultiplied by the alpha channel to improve performance.
Other {@link https://www.khronos.org/registry/webgl/specs/latest/1.0/#5.2 WebGL context attributes} are also supported. WebGL context attributes cannot be changed after the control is fully initialized.
webGLContextAttributes.helpDescription:
Optional WebGL context attributes. A JSON object with the following boolean properties:
  • antialias {boolean} default value true. If set to true, the context will attempt to perform antialiased rendering if possible.

  • premultipliedAlpha {boolean} default value false. If set to true, the color channels in the framebuffer will be stored premultiplied by the alpha channel to improve performance.
Other {@link https://www.khronos.org/registry/webgl/specs/latest/1.0/#5.2 WebGL context attributes} are also supported. WebGL context attributes cannot be changed after the control is fully initialized.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.RedlineConversation.description: Provides a base class control for RedlineConversations.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineConversation.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RedlineConversation. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getConversationName conversationName} : string
    • {@link #getTimestamp timestamp} : int
    • {@link #getViewId viewId} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getViewInfo viewInfo} : any
    • {@link #getAnimationOffset animationOffset} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getMeasurementScale measurementScale} : float (default: 1)
    • {@link #getPageId pageId} : int (default: -1)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getComments comments} : sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementComment[]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineConversation.helpDescription: Provides a base class control for RedlineConversations.

sap.ui.vk.BaseNodeProxy.description:
Provides a simple, lightweight proxy object to a node in a node hierarchy. The objects of this class should not be created directly, and should only be created through the use of the following methods:
  • {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#enumerateChildren sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.enumerateChildren}
  • {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#enumerateAncestors sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.enumerateAncestors}
  • {@link sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManager#enumerateSelection sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManager.enumerateSelection}
sap.ui.vk.BaseNodeProxy.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new BaseNodeProxy. The objects of this class should not be created directly, and should only be created through the use of the following methods:
  • {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#enumerateChildren sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.enumerateChildren}
  • {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#enumerateAncestors sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.enumerateAncestors}
  • {@link sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManager#enumerateSelection sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManager.enumerateSelection}
Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object. This class does not have its own settings, but all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.Object#constructor sap.ui.base.Object} can be used.

sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementLine.constructorDescription:
Redline element control for line. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getDeltaX deltaX} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getDeltaY deltaY} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getEndArrowHead endArrowHead} : boolean (default: false)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement#constructor sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementLine.helpDescription: Provides a control for creating line redline elements.

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.ViewGallery.description: Enables capabilities for navigating and activating procedures and steps contained in a single 3D scene.
sap.ui.vk.ViewGallery.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ViewGallery. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getShowAnimationTimeSlider showAnimationTimeSlider} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowToolbar showToolbar} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getShowThumbnailContainer showThumbnailContainer} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getSelectedViewIndex selectedViewIndex} : int (default: -1)
    • {@link #getSelectedViewGroupIndex selectedViewGroupIndex} : int (default: -1)
    • {@link #getEnableViewReordering enableViewReordering} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getTransparency transparency} : float (default: 1)
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
  • Aggregations
  • Associations
    • {@link #getAnimationPlayer animationPlayer} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.AnimationPlayer)
    • {@link #getContentConnector contentConnector} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector)
    • {@link #getHost host} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase)
    • {@link #getViewManager viewManager} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ViewManager)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:selectionChange selectionChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:viewOrderChange viewOrderChange} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.ViewGallery.helpDescription: Enables capabilities for navigating and activating procedures and steps contained in a single 3D scene.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

sap.ui.vk.tools.CreateRectangleTool.description: The CreateRectangleTool allows applications to create a rectangle/square svg element.
sap.ui.vk.tools.CreateRectangleTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new CreateRectangleTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getParentNode parentNode} : any
    • {@link #getUniformMode uniformMode} : boolean (default: false)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:completed completed} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.CreateRectangleTool.helpDescription: The CreateRectangleTool allows applications to create a rectangle/square svg element.

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

avatar.description: A sap.m.Avatar control instance that, if set, is used instead of an icon or image. The size of the Avatar control depends on the insetIcon property of StandardListItem. The displaySize property of the Avatar control is not supported. If the insetIcon property of StandardListItem is set to true, the size of the Avatar control is set to XS; if the insetIcon property of StandardListItem is set to false, the size of the Avatar control is set to "S".

The displaySize property of the Avatar control is not supported. If the insetIcon property of StandardListItem is set to true, the size of the Avatar control is set to XS; if the insetIcon property of StandardListItem is set to false, the size of the Avatar control is set to "S".

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

wrapCharLimit.description: This property can be used to change the default character limits for the wrapping behavior. If this property is set to 0, then the default character limit used by the wrapping behavior is used. For details see {@link #getWrapping wrapping}. Note: 0 or a positive integer must be used for this property.
wrapCharLimit.helpDescription: This property can be used to change the default character limits for the wrapping behavior. Note: 0 or a positive integer must be used for this property.

activeIcon.description: Defines the icon that is shown while the list item is pressed.
activeIcon.helpDescription: Defines the icon that is shown while the list item is pressed.

highlight.description: Defines the highlight state of the list items. Valid values for the highlight property are values of the enumerations {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType} or {@link sap.ui.core.IndicationColor} (only values of Indication01 to Indication10 are supported for accessibility contrast reasons). Accessibility support is provided through the associated {@link sap.m.ListItemBase#setHighlightText highlightText} property. If the highlight property is set to a value of {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType}, the highlightText property does not need to be set because a default text is used. However, the default text can be overridden by setting the highlightText property. In all other cases the highlightText property must be set.
highlight.helpDescription: Defines the highlight state of the list items. Valid values for the highlight property are values of the enumerations {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType} or {@link sap.ui.core.IndicationColor} (only values of Indication01 to Indication10 are supported for accessibility contrast reasons). Accessibility support is provided through the associated {@link sap.m.ListItemBase#setHighlightText highlightText} property. If the highlight property is set to a value of {@link module:sap/ui/core/message/MessageType}, the highlightText property does not need to be set because a default text is used. However, the default text can be overridden by setting the highlightText property. In all other cases the highlightText property must be set.

fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. Once a logical field group is left, the validateFieldGroup event is fired. For backward compatibility with older releases, field group IDs are syntactically not limited, but it is suggested to use only valid {@link sap.ui.core.ID}s. See {@link #attachValidateFieldGroup} or consult the {@link topic:5b0775397e394b1fb973fa207554003e Field Group} documentation.

wrapping.description:
Defines the wrapping behavior of title and description texts. Note: In the desktop mode, initial rendering of the control contains 300 characters along with a button to expand and collapse the text whereas in the phone mode, the character limit is set to 100 characters.
A wrapping of the information text is supported as of 1.95. But expanding and collapsing the information text is not possible. A wrapping of the information text is disabled if infoStateInverted is set to true.

adaptTitleSize.description: By default, the title size adapts to the available space and gets bigger if the description is empty. If you have list items with and without descriptions, this results in titles with different sizes. In this case, it can be better to switch the size adaption off by setting this property to false.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.tools.MoveTool.description: Tool used to move objects in 3D space
sap.ui.vk.tools.MoveTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new MoveTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getCoordinateSystem coordinateSystem} : sap.ui.vk.tools.CoordinateSystem (default: World)
    • {@link #getPlacementMode placementMode} : sap.ui.vk.tools.GizmoPlacementMode (default: ObjectCenter)
    • {@link #getEnableStepping enableStepping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEnableSnapping enableSnapping} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getShowEditingUI showEditingUI} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAutoResetValues autoResetValues} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAllowContextMenu allowContextMenu} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getNodeSet nodeSet} : sap.ui.vk.tools.ToolNodeSet (default: Highlight)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:moving moving} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:moved moved} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:coordinateSystemChanged coordinateSystemChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:placementModeChanged placementModeChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.MoveTool.helpDescription: Tool used to move objects in 3D space

    • {@link #event:pageChanged pageChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:documentReplaced documentReplaced} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase#constructor sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase} can be used as well.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.Annotation.description: Annotation allows applications to display custom html annotation on top of Viewport and associate it with 3D object
sap.ui.vk.Annotation.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Annotation. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getAnnotationId annotationId} : string
    • {@link #getName name} : string
    • {@link #getNodeRef nodeRef} : any
    • {@link #getText text} : string (default: "")
    • {@link #getStyle style} : sap.ui.vk.AnnotationStyle (default: Default)
    • {@link #getDisplay display} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getAnimate animate} : boolean (default: true)
    • {@link #getAnimationDelay animationDelay} : float (default: -1)
    • {@link #getSelected selected} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getEditable editable} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getXCoordinate xCoordinate} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getYCoordinate yCoordinate} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getXOffset xOffset} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getYOffset yOffset} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getHeight height} : float
    • {@link #getWidth width} : float
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getTextEditor textEditor} : sap.ui.core.Control
  • Associations
    • {@link #getViewport viewport} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.Viewport)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.Annotation.helpDescription: Annotation allows applications to display custom html annotation on top of Viewport and associate it with 3D object

sap.ui.vk.tools.RedlineTool.description: The RedlineTool allows applications to display custom tooltip text on top of 3D object over which pointer is hovering
sap.ui.vk.tools.RedlineTool.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new RedlineTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getEditable editable} : boolean (default: true)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getRedlineElements redlineElements} : sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:elementCreated elementCreated} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:elementClicked elementClicked} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:elementHovered elementHovered} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.RedlineTool.helpDescription: The RedlineTool allows applications to display custom tooltip text on top of 3D object over which pointer is hovering

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement.description: Provides a base class for redline elements.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement.constructorDescription:
Base class for redline elements such as {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementRectangle}, {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementEllipse}, {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementFreehand}, {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementLine}, {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementText}. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getOriginX originX} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getOriginY originY} : float (default: 0)
    • {@link #getOpacity opacity} : float (default: 1)
    • {@link #getStrokeWidth strokeWidth} : float (default: 2)
    • {@link #getStrokeColor strokeColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "#e6600d")
    • {@link #getStrokeDashArray strokeDashArray} : float[] (default: [])
    • {@link #getHalo halo} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getHaloColor haloColor} : string (default: "rgba(255, 0, 0, 1)")
    • {@link #getCreatedByUser createdByUser} : any (default: "")
    • {@link #getCreateTimestamp createTimestamp} : int
    • {@link #getDeletedByUser deletedByUser} : any (default: "")
    • {@link #getDeleteTimestamp deleteTimestamp} : int
    • {@link #getSuppress suppress} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getElementId elementId} : string
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement.helpDescription: Provides a base class for redline elements.

sap.ui.vk.FlexibleControl.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new FlexibleControl. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • {@link #getLayout layout} : string (default: "Stacked")
    • {@link #getEnabled enabled} : boolean (default: true)
  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContent content} : sap.ui.core.Control[] (default)
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.

In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.Notifications.description: Provides the ability to display logged console messages within your application.
sap.ui.vk.Notifications.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Notifications. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
  • Events
    • {@link #event:allMessagesCleared allMessagesCleared} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:messageAdded messageAdded} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.Notifications.helpDescription: Provides the ability to display logged console messages within your application.

sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.description: Provides an object that owns content resources, tracks their changes and loads and destroys the content built from the content resources.
sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ContentConnector. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Aggregations
    • {@link #getContentResources contentResources} : sap.ui.vk.ContentResource[] (default)
    • {@link #getViewStateManagers viewStateManagers} : sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManagerBase[]
  • Events
    • {@link #event:contentChangesStarted contentChangesStarted} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:contentChangesFinished contentChangesFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:contentChangesProgress contentChangesProgress} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:contentLoadingFinished contentLoadingFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:contentReplaced contentReplaced} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:contentDestroying contentDestroying} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Element#constructor sap.ui.core.Element} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector.helpDescription: Provides an object that owns content resources, tracks their changes and loads and destroys the content built from the content resources.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementEllipse.description: Provides a control for creating ellipse redline elements.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementEllipse.constructorDescription:
Redline element control for ellipse. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getRadiusX radiusX} : float (default: 0.0001)
    • {@link #getRadiusY radiusY} : float (default: 0.0001)
    • {@link #getFillColor fillColor} : sap.ui.core.CSSColor (default: "rgba(0, 0, 0, 0)")
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement#constructor sap.ui.vk.RedlineElement} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.RedlineElementEllipse.helpDescription: Provides a control for creating ellipse redline elements.

In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.

sap.ui.vk.ecad.ElementsPanel.description:
Provides a list of all ECAD elements in a given scene in table format. NOTE: To use this control the application developer should add dependencies to the following libraries on application level to ensure that the libraries are loaded before the module dependencies will be required:
  • sap.f
  • sap.ui.comp
sap.ui.vk.ecad.ElementsPanel.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ElementsPanel. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getWidth width} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "auto")
    • {@link #getHeight height} : sap.ui.core.CSSSize (default: "100%")
  • Aggregations
  • Associations
    • {@link #getContentConnector contentConnector} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector)
    • {@link #getViewStateManager viewStateManager} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManagerBase)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:contentChanged contentChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.core.Control#constructor sap.ui.core.Control} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.ecad.ElementsPanel.helpDescription:
Provides a list of all ECAD elements in a given scene in table format. NOTE: To use this control the application developer should add dependencies to the following libraries on application level to ensure that the libraries are loaded before the module dependencies will be required:
  • sap.f
  • sap.ui.comp

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

fieldGroupIds.description: The IDs of a logical field group that this control belongs to. All fields in a logical field group should share the same fieldGroupId. sap.ui.vk.dvl.Viewport.description: Provides a rendering canvas for the 3D elements of a loaded scene.
sap.ui.vk.dvl.Viewport.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new Viewport. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getBackgroundColorTopABGR backgroundColorTopABGR} : int (default: 0xff000000)
    • {@link #getBackgroundColorBottomABGR backgroundColorBottomABGR} : int (default: 0xffffffff)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:pan pan} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:zoom zoom} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:rotate rotate} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:frameRenderingFinished frameRenderingFinished} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase#constructor sap.ui.vk.ViewportBase} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.dvl.Viewport.helpDescription:
Deprecated! Since 1.72.0 DVL namespace will be removed in future. Use {@link sap.ui.vk.Viewport} instead.
Provides a rendering canvas for the 3D elements of a loaded scene.

DeprecatedInfo.description: DVL namespace will be removed in future. Use {@link sap.ui.vk.Viewport} instead.

layoutData.description: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.
layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

busyIndicatorSize.description: The size of the BusyIndicator. For controls with a width smaller 3rem a sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Small should be used. If the size could vary in width and the width could get smaller than 3rem, the sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Auto option could be used. The default is set to sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Medium For a full screen BusyIndicator use sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize.Large.

Constructor for a new CrossSectionTool. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties

In addition, all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool#constructor sap.ui.vk.tools.Tool} can be used as well.
sap.ui.vk.tools.CrossSectionTool.helpDescription: The CrossSection tool can be used to cut all 3D objects along one of three spatial axis to expose their internal structures.

In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.

sap.ui.vk.LayerProxy.description:
Provides a proxy object to the layer in the node hierarchy.

Layer is a list of nodes. One node hierarchy can have multiple layers. One node can be included in multiple layers.

Objects of this type should only be created with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#createLayerProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.createLayerProxy} method and destroyed with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#destroyLayerProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.destroyLayerProxy} method.
sap.ui.vk.LayerProxy.constructorDescription: Constructor for a new LayerProxy. Objects of this type should only be created with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#createLayerProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.createLayerProxy} method and destroyed with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#destroyLayerProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.destroyLayerProxy} method. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object. This class does not have its own settings, but all settings applicable to the base type {@link sap.ui.base.Object#constructor sap.ui.base.Object} can be used.
sap.ui.vk.LayerProxy.helpDescription:
Provides a proxy object to the layer in the node hierarchy.

Layer is a list of nodes. One node hierarchy can have multiple layers. One node can be included in multiple layers.

Objects of this type should only be created with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#createLayerProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.createLayerProxy} method and destroyed with the {@link sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy#destroyLayerProxy sap.ui.vk.NodeHierarchy.destroyLayerProxy} method.

sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManagerBase.description: Manages the visibility and selection states of nodes in the scene.
sap.ui.vk.ViewStateManagerBase.constructorDescription:
Constructor for a new ViewStateManagerBase. Accepts an object literal mSettings that defines initial property values, aggregated and associated objects as well as event handlers. See {@link sap.ui.base.ManagedObject#constructor} for a general description of the syntax of the settings object.

The supported settings are:

  • Properties
    • {@link #getShouldTrackVisibilityChanges shouldTrackVisibilityChanges} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getRecursiveSelection recursiveSelection} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getRecursiveOutlining recursiveOutlining} : boolean (default: false)
    • {@link #getFeatures features} : string[] (default: [])
  • Associations
    • {@link #getContentConnector contentConnector} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ContentConnector)
    • {@link #getViewManager viewManager} : (sap.ui.core.ID | sap.ui.vk.ViewManager)
  • Events
    • {@link #event:visibilityChanged visibilityChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:selectionChanged selectionChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:outliningChanged outliningChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:opacityChanged opacityChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:tintColorChanged tintColorChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:nodeHierarchyReplaced nodeHierarchyReplaced} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:highlightColorChanged highlightColorChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:transformationChanged transformationChanged} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:viewStateApplying viewStateApplying} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]
    • {@link #event:viewStateApplied viewStateApplied} : fnListenerFunction or [fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject] or [oData, fnListenerFunction, oListenerObject]

layoutData.helpDescription: Defines the layout constraints for this control when it is used inside a Layout. LayoutData classes are typed classes and must match the embedding Layout. See VariantLayoutData for aggregating multiple alternative LayoutData instances to a single Element.

tooltip.description: The tooltip that should be shown for this Element. In the most simple case, a tooltip is a string that will be rendered by the control and displayed by the browser when the mouse pointer hovers over the control's DOM. In this variant, tooltip behaves like a simple control property. Controls need to explicitly support this kind of tooltip as they have to render it, but most controls do. Exceptions will be documented for the corresponding controls (e.g. sap.ui.core.HTML does not support tooltips). Alternatively, tooltip can act like a 0..1 aggregation and can be set to a tooltip control (an instance of a subclass of sap.ui.core.TooltipBase). In that case, the framework will take care of rendering the tooltip control in a popup-like manner. Such a tooltip control can display arbitrary content, not only a string. UI5 currently does not provide a recommended implementation of TooltipBase as the use of content-rich tooltips is discouraged by the Fiori Design Guidelines. Existing subclasses of TooltipBase therefore have been deprecated. However, apps can still subclass from TooltipBase and create their own implementation when needed (potentially taking the deprecated implementations as a starting point). See the section {@link https://experience.sap.com/fiori-design-web/using-tooltips/ Using Tooltips} in the Fiori Design Guideline.
